questions.text: An otherwise healthy 15-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother 1 hour after having a single episode of generalized tonic-clonic seizure, which stopped spontaneously after 1 minute. He was sleepy initially but is now awake and alert. His mother reports that he has had a fever and runny nose for the past 3 days. His temperature is 40.1°C (104.2°F). Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Analysis of his cerebrospinal fluid shows 3 cells/mm3, a glucose concentration of 68 mg/dL, and a protein concentration of 35 mg/dL. Administration of a drug that acts through which of the following mechanisms of action is most appropriate in this patient?

choices.text: Increasing frequency of Cl− channel opening
Increasing duration of Cl− channel opening

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Benzodiazepines such as diazepam and lorazepam have an antiseizure effect that is due to their ability to increase the frequency of Cl− channel opening. Lorazepam is often administered as an abortive treatment for prolonged (≥ 5 min) and repetitive febrile seizures. However, this patient has had a single seizure that resolved by itself.

B) INCORRECT:

Phenytoin and carbamazepine have an antiseizure effect that is due to their ability to block voltage-gated Na+ channels. Phenytoin is used for the treatment of prolonged and repetitive seizures that are refractory to initial benzodiazepine administration (i.e., febrile status epilepticus). However, this patient has had a single febrile seizure that resolved by itself.

C) INCORRECT:

Barbiturates such as phenobarbital and thiopental alter neuronal excitability by increasing the duration of Cl− channel opening. Phenobarbital is used as an antiseizure drug in resource-limited settings, while thiopental is used as an IV anesthetic. Although preventive treatment with phenobarbital may reduce the risk of recurrent febrile seizures, long-term antiseizure drug treatment is not indicated in patients with simple febrile seizures because the risks generally outweigh potential benefits.

D) CORRECT:

Antipyretics (NSAIDs and acetaminophen) restore the central thermoregulatory set-point back to normal by decreasing the production of prostaglandin E2. Short-term antipyretic treatment is indicated in children with high fever in order to decrease discomfort and insensible water loss. Symptomatic fever management is the treatment approach for children with simple febrile seizures who do not require antiseizure medication. However, the use of antipyretics does not reduce the risk of recurrent febrile seizures.

External cooling is generally not indicated in previously well children with fever, but it is the treatment of choice for heat stroke, in which more rapid body temperature reduction is needed in order to prevent end-organ damage.

E) INCORRECT:

Cephalosporins and penicillins inhibit transpeptidase cross-linking during bacterial cell wall synthesis by blocking penicillin-binding proteins (transpeptidase). These antibiotics are used in the treatment of bacterial meningitis, which can manifest with fever and seizure. However, since this patient's normal CSF analysis excludes bacterial meningitis, there is no indication for antibiotic therapy.

F) INCORRECT:

Ethosuximide has an antiseizure effect that is due to its ability to block T-type Ca2+ channels. It is used in the treatment of absence seizure, which is characterized by a blank stare and cessation of ongoing activities due to brief loss of consciousness, manifesting as 3-Hz spikes and wave discharges on EEG. However, this patient has had a simple febrile seizure.
questions.hint: This patient has had a simple febrile seizure following an upper respiratory infection. Measures should be taken to decrease the patient's body temperature.

questions.text:
A young man, 18 years of age, presents for follow-up 2 months after undergoing craniotomy for resection of a craniopharyngioma, which was discovered during an evaluation of absent pubertal development and panhypopituitarism. The patient reports feeling well except for intermittent fever as high as 39°C at home and an increased appetite.
His current medications are levothyroxine 112 μg once daily, hydrocortisone 20 mg in the morning and 10 mg in the afternoon, desmopressin nasal spray, and testosterone intramuscular injections.
On examination, the patient’s temperature is 38.8°C, his heart rate is 97 beats per minute, his blood pressure is 129/88 mm Hg, and his BMI is 34.2. His craniotomy scar is well-healed with no erythema, tenderness, or drainage. There is no nuchal rigidity. The remainder of the physical examination is normal.
Laboratory evaluation is normal other than a sodium level of 146 mEq/liter (reference range, 136–145) and a thyroid-stimulating hormone level of 0.051 μU/mL (0.5–4.7). His free thyroxine level is 1.8 ng/dL (reference range, 0.8–1.8).
During the 2 weeks before this follow-up visit, two sets of blood cultures, a urinalysis and urine culture, analysis of a cerebrospinal-fluid sample, and a chest radiograph were all normal. An MRI of the head reveals the expected postoperative changes.
Which one of the following causes of fever is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A postoperative wound infection would be characterized by abnormalities on inspection, imaging, or culture that are not present in this case.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient has panhypopituitarism and appears to be receiving appropriate hormone-replacement therapy: hydrocortisone (a glucocorticoid) for the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis and levothyroxine (synthetic thyroid hormone) for the hypothalamic-pituitary-thyroid axis. Of note, the thyroid-stimulating hormone level cannot be used to guide levothyroxine dosing in patients with a central (pituitary or hypothalamic) disorder, because the central process interferes with thyroid-stimulating hormone secretion; rather, the free thyroxine level is used to guide levothyroxine dosing. Hence, this patient is not overrepleted, and overrepletion of thyroid hormone cannot explain the fever.

C) INCORRECT:

A drug reaction is unlikely in a patient who is receiving stable doses of their medications and whose fever is intermittent. In nonsensitized individuals receiving a drug for the first time, the onset of fever is highly variable and differs among drug classes, but it most commonly occurs after 7 to 10 days of drug administration and rapidly reverses after discontinuation of the drug.

D) CORRECT:

Craniopharyngiomas are usually located in the suprasellar area, where they can cause symptoms from mass effect (headaches, visual-field loss), pituitary dysfunction, and hypothalamic dysfunction. Surgical resection may be complicated and sometimes leads to further local destruction.

However, this patient has evidence of hypothalamic dysfunction. He has diabetes insipidus, as he is taking desmopressin and has obesity. In the absence of evidence of infection, the most likely diagnosis is hyperthermia from hypothalamic dysfunction. This is a rare cause of fever — hypothermia is more common — but should be considered when no other cause can be identified in a patient with a known hypothalamic lesion. The patient also has appetite dysregulation, another feature of hypothalamic dysregulation that often results in severe obesity.

Key learning point: The most typical manifestations of anatomical problems of the hypothalamus are change in appetite, change in thirst, and dysregulation of sleep and body temperature.

E) INCORRECT:

Although inadequate glucocorticoid replacement can be associated with fever, the patient’s dosing, blood pressure, and well-being are not consistent with this diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old woman with a history of recurrent peritonitis and pleuritis is hospitalized with sudden severe abdominal pain and one day of fever to 39.0°C. She also describes right-ankle pain and swelling that started 10 days ago. Her only current medication is tramadol. She smokes marijuana daily and drinks 2 to 3 beers on weekends. Her mother is Italian, and her father is of Armenian descent. She graduated from college several years ago and is working as a grocery-store clerk. She has not traveled recently.
Her medical record reveals that she has had recurrent episodes of high fevers (up to 39.5°C), abdominal pain, and pleuritic chest pain since age 13. These episodes usually require hospitalization but resolve without specific intervention within 2 to 3 days. The patient underwent appendectomy and cholecystectomy in her teens. One year ago, during an episode similar to the current one, an exploratory laparoscopy revealed that the peritoneal fluid was purulent but showed no organisms on Gram stain and no bacterial growth after 2 days. The patient has also had recurrent episodes of joint pain that are somewhat transient and have caused her to miss work on numerous occasions. Previous clinicians have documented concern in her chart that this is “drug seeking” behavior or that it is psychiatric in origin.
At today’s visit, the patient has a blood pressure of 110/70 mm Hg, a heart rate of 72 beats per minute, and a maximal temperature of 38.2°C in the past 24 hours. She has no adenopathy, conjunctivitis, pharyngitis, mucosal ulcerations, or rash. Her cardiopulmonary examination is within normal limits. Her abdomen remains tender but is without peritoneal signs. Her right ankle is swollen and has restricted range of motion. There is no other joint involvement.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
15,000 (85% neutrophils)
4500–11,000


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
11
12–16


Platelet count (per mm3)
300,000
150,000–350,000


Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (mm/hr)
90
1–25


C-reactive protein (mg/liter)
60
0.08–3.10


A complete metabolic profile is normal. Antinuclear antibody testing is negative, as are blood cultures.
What is the most likely underlying diagnosis in this case?

choices.text: Tumor necrosis factor receptor-1–associated periodic syndrome

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Familial Mediterranean fever (FMF) is an autoinflammatory disease characterized by recurrent episodes of fevers and serositis that are abrupt in onset, generally lasting 1 to 3 days. FMF occurs in patients with mutations in the MEFV gene, which encodes pyrin, a component of the cryopyrin inflammasome. Although FMF is historically considered an autosomal recessive condition, patients with heterozygous mutations in the MEFV gene can have variable penetrance of disease manifestations, often with milder features. FMF is most prevalent in (but not restricted to) people of Jewish, North African, Arab, Armenian, Persian, and Turkish descent.

Clinical manifestations of FMF include recurrent fevers, abdominal pain, chest pain, joint pain, and erysipelas-like skin lesions, although not all features may be present in any given episode. Patients are typically symptom-free between episodes. Common laboratory findings include leukocytosis (with neutrophilia and bandemia) and elevated inflammatory markers, such as erythrocyte sedimentation rate, C-reactive protein, serum amyloid protein, and fibrinogen. The diagnosis is based on clinical criteria, and genetic testing for the MEFV gene mutation can be used to confirm the diagnosis.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a patient with pediatric onset of recurrent fever and serositis is familial Mediterranean fever.

B) INCORRECT:

Adult-onset Still disease usually manifests with recurrent fevers in a daily or twice-daily pattern over a period of weeks or months. Patients with this disease also experience noninfectious pharyngitis, adenopathy, elevated aminotransferase levels, inflammatory arthritis, splenomegaly, and a faint salmon-colored rash.

C) INCORRECT:

Somatic symptom disorder is a diagnosis of exclusion. It should not cause elevated serum inflammatory markers.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with tumor necrosis factor receptor-1–associated periodic syndrome (TRAPS) typically present with conjunctivitis and periorbital edema, along with febrile episodes that usually last 7 to 21 days. This patient’s febrile episodes are shorter in duration and are not associated with conjunctivitis or periorbital edema.

E) INCORRECT:

Abdominal infection is exceedingly unlikely in this patient, given the recurrence of her condition and the lack of infectious findings. An atypical smoldering peritonitis from mycobacteria or a fungus might be possible, but the patient has no risk factors for recurrent spontaneous bacterial peritonitis, and that diagnosis would not explain her extra-abdominal symptoms.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old girl with a history of recurrent peritonitis and pleuritis is hospitalized with sudden severe abdominal pain and one day of fever to 39.0°C. She also describes right-ankle pain and swelling that started 10 days ago. Her only current medication is tramadol.
Her medical record reveals that she has had four episodes of high fevers (up to 39.5°C), abdominal pain, and pleuritic chest pain since age 15. These episodes have required hospitalization but resolve without specific intervention within 2 to 3 days. Last year, she underwent appendectomy without complication. At that time, an exploratory laparoscopy revealed that the peritoneal fluid was purulent but showed no organisms on Gram stain and no bacterial growth after 2 days. The patient has also had recurrent episodes of joint pain that are somewhat transient and have caused her to miss school on numerous occasions. Previous clinicians have documented concern in her chart that she may be malingering or that the complaints are psychiatric in origin.
She lives at home with her parents; her mother is Italian, and her father is of Armenian descent. She is doing well in school and is on her school’s dance team. She smokes marijuana occasionally and has a few alcoholic drinks with friends on weekends. She has not traveled outside the United States.
At today’s visit, she has a blood pressure of 110/70 mm Hg, a heart rate of 72 beats per minute, and a maximal temperature of 38.2°C in the past 24 hours. She has no adenopathy, conjunctivitis, pharyngitis, mucosal ulcerations, or rash. Her cardiopulmonary examination is within normal limits. Her abdomen remains tender but is without peritoneal signs. Her right ankle is swollen and has restricted range of motion. There is no other joint involvement.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
15,000 (85% neutrophils)
4500–13,000


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
11
12–16


Platelet count (per mm3)
300,000
150,000–450,000


Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (mm/hr)
90
0–20


C-reactive protein (mg/liter)
60
0–5


A complete metabolic profile is normal. Antinuclear antibody testing is negative, as are blood cultures.
What is the most likely underlying diagnosis in this case?

choices.text: Tumor necrosis factor receptor-1–associated periodic syndrome

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Abdominal infection is exceedingly unlikely in this patient, given the recurrence of her condition and the lack of infectious findings. An atypical smoldering peritonitis from mycobacteria or a fungus might be possible, but the patient has no risk factors for recurrent spontaneous bacterial peritonitis, and that diagnosis would not explain her extra-abdominal symptoms.

B) CORRECT:

Familial Mediterranean fever (FMF) is an autoinflammatory disease characterized by recurrent episodes of fevers and serositis that are abrupt in onset, generally lasting 1 to 3 days. FMF occurs in patients with mutations in the MEFV gene, which encodes pyrin, a component of the cryopyrin inflammasome. Although FMF is historically considered an autosomal recessive condition, patients with heterozygous mutations in the MEFV gene can have variable penetrance of disease manifestations, often with milder features. FMF is most prevalent in (but not restricted to) people of Jewish, North African, Arab, Armenian, Persian, and Turkish descent and typically manifests by the time patients reach 20 years of age.

Clinical manifestations of FMF include recurrent fevers, abdominal pain, chest pain, joint pain, and erysipelas-like skin lesions, although not all features may be present in any given episode. Patients are typically symptom-free between episodes. Common laboratory findings include leukocytosis (with neutrophilia and bandemia) and elevated inflammatory markers, such as erythrocyte sedimentation rate, C-reactive protein, serum amyloid protein, and fibrinogen. The diagnosis is based on clinical criteria, and genetic testing for the MEFV gene mutation can be used to confirm the diagnosis.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a patient with pediatric onset of recurrent fever and serositis is familial Mediterranean fever.

C) INCORRECT:

Somatic symptom disorder is a diagnosis of exclusion. It should not cause elevated serum inflammatory markers.

D) INCORRECT:

Patients with tumor necrosis factor receptor-1–associated periodic syndrome (TRAPS) typically present with conjunctivitis and periorbital edema, along with febrile episodes that usually last 7 to 21 days. This patient’s febrile episodes are shorter in duration and are not associated with conjunctivitis or periorbital edema.

E) INCORRECT:

Adult-onset Still disease usually manifests with recurrent fevers in a daily or twice-daily pattern over a period of weeks or months. Patients with this disease also experience noninfectious pharyngitis, adenopathy, elevated aminotransferase levels, inflammatory arthritis, splenomegaly, and a faint salmon-colored rash. There is a bimodal age distribution, with a peak occurring in the late teen years and another in the fourth and fifth decades of life.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man with metastatic non–small cell lung cancer presents to the ED with daily fevers for the past 19 days. He completed his last cycle of palliative chemotherapy five weeks ago. His oncologist has prescribed him two separate 7-day courses of oral antibiotics (first amoxicillin–clavulanate, then levofloxacin) for presumed respiratory infection, which he completed 4 days ago, but the fevers have persisted. He denies cough, dyspnea, dysuria, or abdominal pain. Vital signs are BP, 116/68 mm Hg; P, 91; R, 20; T, 38.8°C (101.8°F); SpO₂, 97% on room air. Examination is unremarkable. Laboratory results show WBC 7.1 ×10³/mm³ with neutrophils 68%, lymphocytes 22%, monocytes 8%, and eosinophils 2%; hemoglobin 11.8 g/dL, hematocrit 35%, and platelets 280 ×10³/mm³; creatinine 0.9 mg/dL; AST 28 U/L, ALT 32 U/L, and total bilirubin 0.7 mg/dL; lactate 1.3 mmol/L, and normal urinalysis. Chest x-ray demonstrates stable metastatic nodules without new infiltrates. Which of the following best explains his persistent fever?

choices.text: Neoplastic fever due to cytokine release from tumor activity
Occult bacterial infection partially treated with recent antibiotics
Fungal infection secondary to chemotherapy-induced immunosuppression
Drug-induced fever secondary to recent chemotherapy
Drug-induced fever secondary to recent antibiotic therapy

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct — Neoplastic fever results from tumor-related cytokine release (e.g., interleukin-1, tumor necrosis factor) and typically occurs in patients with advanced malignancy without evidence of infection. It persists despite appropriate antibiotic therapy and resolves with anti-inflammatory agents such as naproxen or with effective cancer treatment. Recognition prevents unnecessary prolonged antibiotic use and guides oncologic management.

B) INCORRECT:

Persistent fever after a full antibiotic course may raise suspicion for partially treated infection, but the patient’s stable clinical status, normal white cell count, and lack of localizing findings argue against active infection. Persistent fevers in this context should prompt evaluation for noninfectious etiologies.

C) INCORRECT:

Although fungal infections occur in immunocompromised hosts, this patient is not neutropenic and has normal imaging without pulmonary or systemic findings suggestive of fungal disease. The presentation is inconsistent with disseminated fungal infection.

D) INCORRECT:

Drug fever related to cytotoxic chemotherapy generally develops during or shortly after administration and resolves once the agent is cleared. The patient’s last chemotherapy was five weeks ago, making this explanation unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Drug fever is possible after antibiotic exposure but typically develops several days into treatment and resolves after discontinuation. This patient’s fevers preceded antibiotic use and persisted despite cessation, making a drug reaction unlikely. Persistent, unexplained fever in the absence of infection is more consistent with a paraneoplastic process.
